plurilogues.description: A multi-format English debate consisting of an extempore round followed by a face-off final between selected teams.
rules: Each team will receive a word/phrase/term 10 minutes before the start.
Speaker 1 delivers a 1.5-minute extempore speech.
Speaker 2 immediately continues for another 1.5 minutes.
Final includes Block-and-Tackle round with stance changes on jury cues.
Each finalist has 2.5 mins (opening) + 1.5 mins (second) to speak.

continuum.description: An interdisciplinary event where participants present a dialogue about Picasso’s Guernica while creating live paintings.
rules: Two members speak on Guernica; all three paint simultaneously.
Only wax crayons and markers allowed.
No costumes or props except 2 hats, 2 empty frames, 2 umbrellas.
A3 sheets and easels provided by host.
Use stage space creatively; connect artwork to modern context.

quartet.description: A short experimental performance featuring two historical figures, a concept, and one silent performer using gestures.
rules: Team of 4: 3 speakers and 1 silent performer.
Historical characters and abstract concepts must be included.
Only chairs/tables provided, no props, lights or mics.
Time limit: 4.5 mins including entry/exit.
Silent performer must enhance meaning through gestures.

scriptorium.description: Students compose an original 15-line piece blending a short story, monologue, and poem based on a given prompt.
rules: Use the same prompt (word, phrase, or image).
Output must blend 3 genres clearly in 15 lines.
Entries must have a title.
Judged on structure, genre clarity, and creativity.
Submit individual handwritten piece on-site.

sensorium.description: Participants will interpret a multisensory prompt using creative expression across any format — from movement to mime to spoken word.
rules: Prompt will involve at least 3 sensory inputs (sound, smell, touch, visuals).
Only 1 performer from each team; no costume changes.
Time limit: 2.5 minutes max.
No pre-recorded music allowed; live sounds encouraged.
Presentation must reflect the theme's emotional/creative depth.

quest.description: A live multimedia quiz testing general awareness, logic, lateral thinking, and observation skills through written prelims and live finals.
rules: Teams of 2 students; class-mix allowed.
Written round determines 6 finalists.
Quiz includes audio-visual and rapid fire rounds.
No mobile phones allowed during the event.
Audience interaction rounds may be included.

crossconnect.description: Teams must present a 5-minute concept pitch integrating two or more academic disciplines using real-world problems or stories.
rules: Team of 2 students from different subject backgrounds.
Presentation must include visuals (can be digital or handmade).
No reading from scripts allowed.
Focus on originality, clarity, and interdisciplinary depth.
No internet-connected devices allowed during the event.

biblioquest.description: Participants follow clues, solve puzzles, and navigate research-based tasks across books, catalogues, and archive materials.
rules: Team of 3 students.
No mobile devices allowed.
Use of library catalogue and index encouraged.
All answers must be written down and submitted on time.
Focus on speed, accuracy, and decoding ability.

newstrack.description: Teams present an investigative report (real or imagined) including background, facts, interviews, and possible solutions.
rules: Teams of 2 students.
One student anchors the presentation; the other plays a reporter/interviewee.
Use of visual props or slides allowed but not mandatory.
Presentations must be under 4 minutes.
Judged on clarity, impact, and journalistic depth.

visualvocabulary.description: Students create a visual collage illustrating 3 selected vocabulary words with pictures, cutouts, drawings, and captions.
rules: Individual event.
A3 sheet to be provided; only dry materials allowed.
Each word must have a heading, image, and 1-line caption.
Words should be level-appropriate and creatively presented.
No digital elements allowed.

unreimagined.description: Participants represent countries in a reimagined UN setup to address modern global crises through policy presentation and debate.
rules: Each team represents one country.
Delegates must propose resolutions to a crisis revealed on the day.
Spoken and written communication will be assessed.
Judged on diplomacy, collaboration, and realism of policy.
No props or costumes allowed.
